channel.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
channel.description:
In regards to private servers, maybe 90% of us here on MoparScape couldn't program one to be the most efficient we could make it (including me).
Bearing that in mind, should I create something from a source that is just hard-coded or [i]wait[/i] 10 years until I've been to college and aquired a job as a programmer? Because I don't want to be just another hard-coder but what choice do I really have. If I make something now, it'll be for originality and features, not for performace and efficiency, because plain and simply, I can't.
Now, you may say [i]don't bother messing with Java until you know all about proper conventions and clean-coding[/i], but I can make it more efficient later, after I've done want I wanted.
I want to know your opinion.

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @SunSpec221 SunSpec221
item.description:
@SunSpec221 wrote:

I would say learn from the best. That is what i try to do, it has worked but things i don’t understand just make me go all weird. When you finish your so happy, but if the server stuff’s up you go… what the fuck!

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

code aesthetic usually boils down to personal opinion, but code efficiency never does. there are benchmarks you can run and such which are undoubtedly objective to prove which is more efficient in each specific case

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:26, topic:370740”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=466835.msg3414539#msg3414539 date=1290952819]
Avoiding hardcoding is rather easy:
You load stuff from files instead of sticking them in the source code and use clear,
Use multi functional methods instead of sticking everything into the same if or switch statement.

In my personal opinion efficient programming isn’t something you learn from a book, it’s just common logic sense most of the time and a basic understanding of what a computer has to process. There are a couple of features in a programming language that you might have to learn like bitshifts, bitwise operators or the “condition ? true : false” thing in java (i forgot the name ) but those are things you can teach yourself.

Take the example of filling 2 arrays with numbers 0 to 9
A Linear approach would be:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            dos[i] = i;
        }

A more efficient way is just common sense:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
            dos[i] = i;
        }

Or you could even use the Arrays.copyOf(int[] array, int length) for an even more efficient way!

The first snippet has to iterate 20 times whereas the second only has to iterate 10 times.

[/quote]ternary operator

and how exactly is Arrays.copyOf more efficient in this particular scenario? it invokes the jni upon invocation of the native System.arraycopy function and although this may be faster for larger arrays, for smaller arrays it would probably end up being slower[/quote]

You see, at the same time it can boil down to just personal opinion or preference; so who’s to say what’s best?

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:25, topic:370740”]Avoiding hardcoding is rather easy:
You load stuff from files instead of sticking them in the source code and use clear,
Use multi functional methods instead of sticking everything into the same if or switch statement.

In my personal opinion efficient programming isn’t something you learn from a book, it’s just common logic sense most of the time and a basic understanding of what a computer has to process. There are a couple of features in a programming language that you might have to learn like bitshifts, bitwise operators or the “condition ? true : false” thing in java (i forgot the name ) but those are things you can teach yourself.

Take the example of filling 2 arrays with numbers 0 to 9
A Linear approach would be:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            dos[i] = i;
        }

A more efficient way is just common sense:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
            dos[i] = i;
        }

Or you could even use the Arrays.copyOf(int[] array, int length) for an even more efficient way!

The first snippet has to iterate 20 times whereas the second only has to iterate 10 times.[/quote]ternary operator

and how exactly is Arrays.copyOf more efficient in this particular scenario? it invokes the jni upon invocation of the native System.arraycopy function and although this may be faster for larger arrays, for smaller arrays it would probably end up being slower

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Avoiding hardcoding is rather easy:
You load stuff from files instead of sticking them in the source code and use clear,
Use multi functional methods instead of sticking everything into the same if or switch statement.

In my personal opinion efficient programming isn’t something you learn from a book, it’s just common logic sense most of the time and a basic understanding of what a computer has to process. There are a couple of features in a programming language that you might have to learn like bitshifts, bitwise operators or the “condition ? true : false” thing in java (i forgot the name ) but those are things you can teach yourself.

Take the example of filling 2 arrays with numbers 0 to 9
A Linear approach would be:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            dos[i] = i;
        }

A more efficient way is just common sense:

        int[] uno = new int[10];
        int[] dos = new int[10];

        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
            uno[i] = i;
            dos[i] = i;
        }

Or you could even use the Arrays.copyOf(int[] array, int length) for an even more efficient way!

The first snippet has to iterate 20 times whereas the second only has to iterate 10 times.

Read full topic

A lot of good programmers don’t learn that much more in college. You’d be better off going to the book store

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

A lot of good programmers don’t learn that much more in college. You’d be better off going to the book store and buying a good programming book and going from there. If it makes you happy, then do it. The way I taught myself, was just trying to program new things. I would read from the sun tutorials and then try to do it without having to revert back to the tutorial.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

So my title should really read “Unefficiency and Efficiency”.

Hard-coding is basically typing up aload of unorganised quick input crap? Yes, this is not what I had in mind when typing up my OP.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @k0_twin k0 twin
item.description:
@k0_twin wrote:

“hard-code” is not the best term to use to describe what you’re talking about.

Generally programming wise, hard-coding is embedding input into the source code or the exe (some kind of fixed format) instead of obtaining the code from an external source (let’s say, user input) or generating it.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote="`Alec, post:2, topic:370750"][quote author=the elve age link=topic=466835.msg3413873#msg3413873 date=1290906176]
P.S. its not called “coding” its called programming.
[/quote]

You are a moron.

[hr]

@OP I don’t think it would take you 10 years to go to college, and you don’t need to go to college to be a decent programmer…[/quote]

Okay more like 5 years (college and a job - I want to be an IT tech.), college may not be necessary, but still may be the easier option.

Experience is everything though. Hence fourth I believe if I just hard-coded because I can and then one day when I’m happy wade on through optimising, piece by piece.

I really do think this. As I’m not gonna kid myself, I can’t write something that everyone’s going to be happy with. I just want some acceptance on the fact that hard-coding is sometimes the only way, temporarily.

We can’t be hypocritical about it.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

Well it’s not hard-programming now, is it. :rolleyes:

Edit: and there will always be a better, more efficient way that someone will find so you’re forever optimising. Now that’s all fun and dandy, but you’ll never be happy, will you?

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

Honestly no one wants a source that you made, because if your not going to do it correct don’t do it at all. If you know how to use it in RSPS, and you can’t anywhere else, you didn’t learn how to do it correctly.

P.S. its not called “coding” its called programming.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @k0_twin k0 twin
item.description:
@k0_twin wrote:

For me, I have to read about something long enough so that I understand it conceptually, but after that I HAVE to practice with it or else I never learn.

For example, last year I was reading about advanced concepts relating to classes (polymorphism, inheritance etc) and I had to practice over and over and over until I finally had an understanding of any of it. Just reading about it wasn’t enough. But that’s just me.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard-coding and Efficiency
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:7, topic:370740”][quote author=Mendorphins link=topic=466835.msg3413735#msg3413735 date=1290898006]
This is a serious question by the way. What do you mean by un-nested?

Learn what needs to be learnt now and then go back and attempt to become a better, cleaner, efficient programmer.

Yeah, that’s basically it I suppose. What was your journey like to becoming who you are now, regarding programming of course.
[/quote]
Haha… I’m still in that beginner setting. I’ve gotten the reputation because of helping, reporting, being nice, and like 2% from Bronze Age. I’ve started with Deltascape which led me to become or want to become a better programmer. At the moment I’m working with Hyperion, but however, RSPS is going to teach nothing that needs to be taught.[/quote]

Not doubt about it. The pros on this forum have obviously been elsewhere first, but I seem to understand the concepts a bit better if there’s some sort of RS related reference in it.

I’m having a dilemma at the moment on what to do, where to begin, what to be happy with. There’s always one flaw or one barrier that stops me and then I lose interest.

Not good I suppose, going to have to perservere a bit more, lol.

[quote=“Scape-JAVA, post:1, topic:370750”][quote author=Liquid Magic link=topic=466835.msg3413730#msg3413730 date=1290897914]
unnested if statements are cool too
[/quote]

i liak triple nested.

@OP
Learning to program properly is the key to programming efficiently, for example, this is very messy/inefficient code

if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("master") && playerRights = 2) { addSkillXP(14000000, 0); addSkillXP(14000000, 1); addSkillXP(14000000, 2); addSkillXP(14000000, 3); addSkillXP(14000000, 4); addSkillXP(14000000, 5); addSkillXP(14000000, 6); addSkillXP(14000000, 7); addSkillXP(14000000, 8); addSkillXP(14000000, 9); addSkillXP(14000000, 10); addSkillXP(14000000, 11); addSkillXP(14000000, 12); addSkillXP(14000000, 13); addSkillXP(14000000, 14); addSkillXP(14000000, 15); addSkillXP(14000000, 16); addSkillXP(14000000, 17); addSkillXP(14000000, 18); addSkillXP(14000000, 19); addSkillXP(14000000, 20); addSkillXP(14000000, 21); }

you can easily make it clean code by learning to program properly, for example.

if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("master") && playerRights >= 2) { for(int i = 0; i < 21; i++) { addSkillXP(14000000, i); } }

I know it’s rsps but it’s an example.[/quote]

When I say hard-code, I was meant to make an exception about the i++; or the “something : somethingElse ?” thing (lol?). But yeah cheers.

Also, this is what I mean about concept, I’d know how to use i++ in ::master, but I wouldn’t know how or even what to use it for anywhere else, non-RSPS related.

Read full topic
